Actually, considering many dairy farms raise their cows on pasture, milk from cows does the least damage because it doesn't require any deforestation, unlike every other method you mentioned. Pastures aren't suited to grow almonds, soy, or coconuts so the land use (by which I believe you mean habitat displacement) is zero...
Plus, with rotational crop agriculture you can reduce the net carbon emissions to zero and many companies are starting to implement this. Lastly, they drink RAINWATER, so you're not taking water out of lakes and rivers to give to them like you do with massive fields of plants in the California desert. Cows are by far the most natural and eco-friendly milk when you start to understand their role in nature from a bigger perspective.

My Daughter has some allergies and sinus problems. Most nuts, she's allergic to. So she can't have most nut milks. We found that cow's milk, if taken in regular-large doses, would worsen the severity of her problems; so to help reduce them, we tried an alternative milk - goat's milk... She used to get an upset stomach and head, before we gave her the goat's milk. Now, she doesn't get as many problems from milk consumption. Since then, we've also tried lactose free milks, rice milk, soy milk and coconut milk. Now, when she drinks them, she has no stomach problems. This even applies to yoghurt, cheese and ice creams. You didn't mention goat's milk? On a similar note, regarding ice-creams; sorbets are a good alternative, for her. And she can still have dairy; just in small amounts, and on-occasion.

One of the nutritional benefits of milk and dairy is that it is a high protein source, so it can serve as an alternative to meat.  Milk has 8 grams of protein per 8 oz. cup.  All of these plant-based milks have much less protein--80% to 90% less.  Kids are already eating a ton of cold cereals--the milk they pour on it is the only protein they get.  Swap that for plant milk and now they have a 90% sugar and carb breakfast.

Ummmm...... Nutrition is not inconsequential guys If you aren't giving children dairy milk, you need to choose fortified soy milk or blended nut/pea protein milk. Almond milk will not work. There is a good reason why vegan kids given nothing but oat milk or almond milk are ending up with nutritional deficiencies and serious problems. Not saying there aren't healthy ways to raise a kid vegan or dairy free but when a parent sees "milk" alternatives, they choose something without realizing it is not complete enough for a kid.  Adults can fret about what to put in their coffee or cereal, but most milk sold is going to young kids. Additionally, the "greenest"options are often unfortified with necessary vitamins and calcium. It's honestly dangerous for almond milk and oat milk to even be sold as "milk" because many parents don't understand the difference. I get that you're focus was the environmental impact but you guys gotta look at the big picture.

Though I am lucky enough to be able to afford alternative milks, we can't discount the fact that cow's milk is the least expensive, which is a HUGE decision factor for both individuals and families who can't afford to think about sustainability. This is a demographic that cannot be ignored. I can get 4 liters of high quality milk for $7 CAD, whereas (in my area anyway) oat milk costs range from $6 CAD for Oatly, up to a whopping $9 CAD for Califia Farms Barista oat milk for 0.95 liters (NOT EVEN ONE LITER).
Economy of scale comes into play here, but for the alternatives to becomes as affordable as cow's milk, production must scale up to levels where their carbon footprint might rival that of cow's milk.
This means that the question is not only of "which milk is best", but also "why must sustainable decisions be so expensive" and "why are people so poor".

Edit: I realize the alternative milks I buy are "barista grade" which are usually more expensive, but even the most basic soy milk is more costly than cow's milk.

It's unclear where the source material is coming from. The BBC sites the same Oxford study, but the graphs they interpret are not included, in fact, milk is only mentioned 8 times in the Oxford Study, and only in the context of dairy or soy. Some caveats missed in this review is the nutrition milk provides, and the inclusion of GHG emissions in the processing and additives requires to make non-dairy milks similar to dairy milk (e.g. matched for protein, calcium, B12 etc., in addition to texturizing additives for mouthfeel etc.).
Based on sourcing, which is a criticism featured in some of these non-plant based milks here, could be applied to dairy, such that some produce GHG emissions similar to rice milk. The overall life cycle +GHG cycle of a dairy cow is not considered here, but somewhat in the Oxford study as they may be utilized for beef production at end of life. Fertilizer production, water cycle (through urination) and other bovine based products are not considered (i.e. hair care products, medications, fire retardants, bone char/charcoal, paint brushes...).

To elaborate on the point about bees and almonds: the bees are shipped to California from across the United States each year while the almond trees are in bloom. This practice started when California's almond orchards were no where near as massive as they are now, but they currently require billions of honey bees to pollinate them each year. There seems to be some contradicting information on the effect that this has on bees, but I've read that it can take weeks or months for hives to recover after being being shipped back (and not all do recover), and that movement and changing directions of the trucks disorients the bees while they're being shipped.

Your presentation makes it appear that the only product of dairy farming is cow's milk, but that's not true.  Beef is the other product, and if you ascribe all of the water / gas emissions / etc costs to milk, then beef is "free" of those environmental costs, and that is not accurate.  The animal husbandry involved here means that if we (society) want beef then milk will be there, and vice versa.  A cow has to have one calf a year to continue in milk production (over their lifetime of 18-20 years).  Or, to put it the other way around, for a cow to produce one calf a year (most of which will go to a slaughterhouse for beef production age about 1), then they're going to produce milk.  So, to be fair/accurate, you should probably cut your cow's milk numbers in half, because the rest of the environmental impact is for beef production.

Your Honorable mentions should include the carbon-neutral cow milk brand Strauss dairy as well as other animal alternatives like goats and sheep’s milk. Also, let’s not forget that this is primarily a white people problem bc most other countries don’t have dairy milk or milk in general as a large part of their diet bc most of the world’s population is lactose intolerant. The USA should not be dependent on or buy large quantities of a product from other countries, especially when there’s no need for it. We don’t have to import soy or rice milk, we can literally just make our own environmentally friendly milk if we want. And the land we currently use for the conventional dairy industry could just be land for goats and sheep, as those animals are smaller and generally need less land, not to mention sheep also provide material like wool. Ultimately, having a mixture of milk sources is the most sustainable decision, because then you’re not putting all the pressure on one industry to supply the world with a single form of food. Also, let’s not forget that it is fundamentally not the consumer that is responsible for global warming, it is corporations and governments not cracking down on those increasing anthropogenic climate change that are responsible, so while sure its important to do your due diligence with regards to making household choices based on the idea of a sustainable and zero waste future, its important not to start blaming an individual for making what you might consider the wrong choice, i.e. conventional dairy milk. As it stands, for a lot of poor people in America, conventional dairy milk is something extremely affordable, incredibly nutritious, and available nearly everywhere. The reason the US even has milk and dairy as a staple in the American diet is bc of the Great Depression and the three reasons listed above. Ergo, from a purely utilitarian perspective, it’s better to drink dairy milk, and a lot of the milk alternatives simply don’t even come close to dairy in those three regards. Finally, let’s talk about the fact that a lot of conventionally grown produce uses a lot of pollutants like pesticides, insecticides, fertilizers, and GMO’s which create their own problems due to their pay to use patents consequently causing a decrease in competition amongst farms. Organically grown produce, while not perfect, does not contribute to nearly the same extent of overall anthropogenic climate change as their conventional alternatives, so you really do have to differentiate between conventionally grown and organically grown produce and their corresponding “milks” because their impacts on the environment will be drastically different. I think this video is a good starting point for people wanting to learn to make changes to their behavior to become eco friendly, but it is not nearly enough. I would suggest making a follow-up video with all of my information and more. Perhaps even touch on the fact that the brand of milk alternative you buy (like is buying a brand of soy milk that is basically owned by Monsanto really better than buying conventional dairy milk) and the store you buy it from matters too. If, as a consumer, you want to have a meaningful positive impact on the environment these are things you really have to do as conscientiously as possible. There’s literally no point in half assing it because these choices are elective, so if you want to become sustainable, that is something you do for yourself and the environment and for no one else, and you should never shame anyone for not doing what you’re doing. You can educate, but never shame unless it’s something really pathetic like littering. People don’t respond well to shaming, educating people on these issues is better. Sorry that was so long, this is just something I’m really passionate about.

Also, for those wondering I am not dissing GMO’s because I think they are physically bad for you, I am dissing them bc of the human impact they have and the monoculture they bring in agriculture.

So I see that the main argument here against consuming dairy milk is the environmental impact, which is a noble cause, I agree. Unfortunately, only production has been taken into consideration here, which isn’t the full picture at all. There is no way that importing alternative milks from the other side of the world is any better than drinking local dairy milks (say, goat milk instead of cow milk) because of the emissions from transporting those milks thousands of kilometres across the world to your supermarket shelves. Coconut milk from Indonesia might have less environmental impact in the place of its production, but that impact is increased with the distance it travels to get to the consumer.

Potential slave and child labour was also touched upon here but that’s only the tip of the exploitation iceberg that exists in corporate trade. A good thing to always keep in mind is that there is no ethical consumption in capitalism. Just because something is labelled as “free trade” doesn’t mean that there are no underpaid workers with bosses above them who rake in the profits, whether it’s in the fields, in factories, in a corporate setting or in stores.

The best thing you can do to lessen your negative environmental and economic impact isn’t just to buy whatever you see on your grocery store shelves that’s lowest on the scale shown here. Instead, buy as locally as you can and buy from smaller producers rather than big corporations. And if your local, small business options include alternatives, great! If not, please carefully weigh if lower water and land use actually have any impact when followed by higher transportation emissions and corporate exploitation.

Very environmentally friendly
I like the taste and texture (incl. protein)
It's cheap! $5/gal

I think it takes around 10x to 12x more soy to feed a cow to produce one unit of beef (calorically) than it would take to produce one unit of tofu directly for human consumption. Although using soy to feed a cow to produce dairy milk (instead of using the soy to make soy milk directly) wouldn't be as bad as beef, it still would require many more magnitudes more land use (and all the other resources like water) to produce one unit of soy milk than dairy milk.

Theres 2 main issues I have with this.

1) It's a faulty direct comparison of "milks" when dairy milk has a 5-10x higher protein level than alternatives. It was only mentioned briefly in the video, but many many people underconsume protein, which also has appetite curbing effects, which would go a long way towards addressing the obesity epidemic (mostly caused by highly refined carbs).

2) You have to sacrifice variety and risk overeating with more environmentally friendly options
39 calories per gram of almond "milk"
19 calories per gram of protein - dairy milk
*outlier* 11 calories per gram of protein - soy milk (this is actually a huge win, please make soy milk more widespread in the US, unfortunately it is still 4x more expensive than dairy milk)

16 calories per gram of protein - black beans
8.5 calories per gram of protein - chicken

In conclusion, alternatives often fall short when considering overall nutrition. It's also going to be a pipe dream changing consumer habits without tackling the issues of prices. The solution needs to start at a political level, abolishing dairy and meat subsidization and making optimal alternatives like soy milk cheaper to buy.

Well, to me the conclusion imposes itself: you want to do something for environment? Drink less milk, or don't use any at all. Because the main problem with alternative milks is that they need to be grown and therefore might cause deforestation. The obvious solution to that is the use of local circuits, if possible.
To me it's the perfect example of the modern trend : finding more or less satisfying ways to keep up the current pace of consumption. But we can't really do that. If we were all to consume alternative milks, how many acres would have to be converted to satisfy the demand? I don't think they are a real solution. The real solution if you want to be eco-friendly is to grow your own plants, and live without electricity.

PS : that's just my opinion though, so feel free to respond and argue with me if you have facts that contradict my beliefs (with respect and politely of course ^^)

Coconut milk - to me this a curry base, not a drink just as it is. It's very tasty, but also very fatty, and I don't think it behaves the same as milk when you're using it as an alternative in cooking. Also don't confuse it with the content of a coconut, which is coconut *water*.
Almond milk - I'm having this now actually, but the flavour, again just on its own, is a bit too characterful for me. I tend to mix it with dairy milk. It's amazing in a cappucino though, but it's difficult to get it it to foam up. And as with coconut milk, I wouldn't use it in cooking because of its strong flavour.
Soy milk - Yeah that's good. Behaves similar to dairy milk in cooking, and the flavour is quite mild. It's also made into other diary products like yoghurt and creme fraiche.
Cashew milk - I've had this recently, but it only works well in puddings and in coffee. On its own, even mixed with dairy milk, the flavour is just too weird. It also gives a "roughness" sensation in the mouth, like black/brown tea does.
Oat milk - THIS IS LOVELY. The flavour is *absolutely amazing*. It works well as an ingredient, or in coffee. It doesn't foam up as much as dairy milk, but still doable. But the flavour is why you're drinking oat milk just on its own. I've also seen this made into a creme fraiche alternative called "oat fresh", and it works and behaves really well in cooking.

I've tried them all, and my favourite is... Use your imagination.

Hey guys, I've been trying to get to the bottom of an environmental issue, that maybe you can look at.

I listened to a documentary on CBC Radio a few years ago about organic farming on the Canadian prairies, (I think the CBC show was "Ideas") in it there was a farmer who has been working to reproduce the natural cycle of mega fauna ungulates (buffalo) whose passing generated remains that birds the used to find insects which then improved the health of the grasslands.

The farmer was using cows and chickens to mimic this cycle, and from what I recall the health of his land was such that it was included in surveys of protected grassland for migratory birds.

I'd love to see an investigation into sustainable biome specific practices for food production. It seems to me that if our farming practices reinforced natural processes, the land use issue is much reduced.
